data.text: Safest Way of Packing a Bike for Air Travel

Hi All. I need your advice on what's the safest way of bringing your bike on a plane. I've traveled from France to Ireland recently. I packed up my bike in a box I got from a local bike shop and wrapped it with a packaging tape carefully. It was lashing rain when I got to Dublin which might explain the stage I found my packaging in. Luckily nothing was missing nor damaged. Have you ever experienced anything like this? What would you advise to avoid it in future? Needless to say Ryanair takes no responsibility for this as "it was raining". Thanks
While it's not ideal, Box did its job. All is good.
data.author: Neil Biking Martin

data.text: Foam self-seal pipe insulation around the frame also helps. The stuff that you stick around your copper pipes under the floorboards. Stops your bars, seats-post etc. tapping on your frame. I've worked at airports and believe me, the baggage chuckers don't give a flying feck about anyone's luggage. I once saw a suitcase fall fifteen foot onto the floor from a conveyor belt and the chucker just threw it back on without a care. By the time it got to the end of the line, the suitcase's contents were all over the belt. A mate of mine saw a top end prototype bike in a case get steamrollered by a forklift. I believe it was £10k's worth. 😒 My advice: Get insured to the hilt, fit Apple Airtags and if you can don't travel by plane. Make your return address details MASSIVE when you put it inside the box. English may not be the first language of the person whom opens the bike box/suitcase and baggage chuckers only briefly glance for any details, so best slap them in the face with your name and the destination of the box. Best tip: remove rear mech. I didn't and the bastards bent my frame and I was using a case where you could keep your rear wheel attached to your bike! The rear mech and hangar were bent at a complete 90 degree angle to the frame and the wheel was fine. Work that one out!!!??? I once spoke to a bloke whom was travelling to Cuba and he watched from the ground as the baggage chucker dropped his cardboard wrapped steed from the aeroplane to the tarmac, as it bounced on it's semi-deflated tyres. Frightening... 😲

data.text: Exactly the same happened to me when flying from Manchester to Calcutta. My boxed bike spent a couple of hours in a tropical rain-storm in Dubai. Papier-maché when it arrived in Calcutta. A word about Ryanair. In July this year at Manchester Airport the check-in person rejected my bike. It was wrapped in heavy-duty plastic, a bag I'd bought on the Internet. Wiggle, I think. I'd used the same packaging before with EasyJet without a problem. "It'll get damaged " she said. So beware of Ryanair. It might be a policy to discourage cyclists. I might just have got the wrong person on checkin. Ryanair need to state exactly what they mean by "protective bag". I've attempted to discuss it with them. They promised a reply but I'm still waiting 2 months later. It's their way of dealing with things, I think. I had to fly next day with Jet2. It cost over £500 inc an overnight hotel at the airport. And a lot of stress.
